lead_paragraph: ANLYAN--William G.,M.D. Dean and Chancellor of Duke University Medical Center 1964-1990, Chancellor of Duke University 1990-1995, and later, trustee of the Duke Endowment for 24 years, died at age 90 on January 17, 2016. Anlyan presided over a major expansion of Duke University Hospital and nearly four million square feet of new or renovated facilities. He oversaw the transformation of Duke's medical school into one of the country's foremost medical centers. An innovator in medical education, he instituted new programs such as the Physician's Assistant Program. During his first year as Dean he procured grants for all 100 medical students. Dr. Anlyan was extraordinarily sensitive to human emotion, and was recognized as a charismatic communicator, able to listen and identify with all. Anlyan grew up in Alexandria, Egypt, the son of a British civil servant. In 1943 he entered Yale College, graduating Magna Cum Laude in 15 months. In 1949 he graduated from Yale with his medical degree. In 1999, he received the Distinguished Alumni Service Award from the Association of Yale Alumni in Medicine. Anlyan was the first chairman of the Association of American Medical Colleges, a founding member of the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences, chair of Research America and a recipient of the Abraham Flexner Award for his contributions to medical education. Active in the World Health Organization, he led a delegation to China in 1975. He was author or editor of nine books and more than 100 medical articles. Survivors include his wife, Alexandra Hufty Anlyan of Durham, NC and Palm Beach, FL; his children and their spouses, Elaine and William G. Anlyan, Jr. of Wilmington, NC, Harriet and J. Peter Anlyan of Durham, NC and Louise Anlyan Harris and Ramsey Dabby of Tenafly, NJ; seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A memorial service was celebrated February 6 at Duke University. Online memorials at: www.hallwynne.com. 1/3
